pages.text: Dicraeosaurus hansemanni was a medium sized sauropod from what is now know as the Lindi Region, Tanzania during the Upper Jurassic. Unlike most Diplodocoids, Dicraeosaurus had a comparatively large head with a relatively short and wide neck. The neck contained 12 unusually short vertebrae, likely indicating a low-level  browser of vegetation no more than 3 meters in height.

Dicraeosaurus meaning 'bifurcated' or 'double-headed lizard', is a genus of diplodocoid sauropod dinosaur that was found in the Tendaguru formation, of Tanzania which dates to the Upper Jurassic. The rocks that Dicraeosaurus fossils are found also yield fossils of Giraffatitan and Kentrosaurus.
